;总统弗拉基米尔·泽伦斯基于周六从土耳其带回了马里乌波尔乌克兰驻军的五名前指挥官俄罗斯称这一具有高度象征意义的成就违反了去年达成的囚犯交换协议。

;

;俄罗斯立即谴责了这次释放。克里姆林宫发言人德米特里·佩斯科夫表示，安卡拉已根据交换协议承诺将这些人留在土耳其，并抱怨莫斯科没有得到通知。

;

;为了纪念战争第 500 天，弗拉基米尔·泽连斯基还访问了蛇岛，俄罗斯军队在入侵当天占领了黑海露头，后来又放弃了。

;

;去年，五名指挥官在亚佐夫斯塔尔钢铁厂领导了马里乌波尔为期三个月的激烈防御后，在乌克兰受到了崇拜俄罗斯占领的最大城市。

;

;“我们正在从土耳其回国，并将我们的英雄带回家，”周五在伊斯坦布尔与土耳其总统雷杰普·塔伊普·埃尔多安举行会谈的弗拉基米尔·泽伦斯基说道。

; >;

;去年初俄罗斯全面入侵乌克兰后不久，港口城市马里乌波尔就成为激烈战斗的中心。这座被俄罗斯军队包围的城市周围的战斗持续了几个月。

;

;数千名乌克兰士兵，其中包括来自另类右翼民族主义亚速团的战士，在亚速斯塔钢铁厂坚守。最后的捍卫者最终于五月投降。

;

;俄罗斯在声称寻求将乌克兰从“法西斯分子”手中“解放”时，多次引用了另类右翼的亚速团。俄罗斯最初计划对被俘的亚速部队进行审判，但后来将几名指挥官驱逐到土耳其，据报道，条件是他们必须留在那里直到战争结束。

;

;莫斯科于 9 月以囚犯身份释放了其中一些人由安卡拉斡旋的交换，根据要求指挥官留在土耳其直到战争结束的条款。

;

;佩斯科夫告诉俄罗斯RIA通讯社：“没有人告诉我们这件事。根据协议，这些头目将留在土耳其领土上，直到冲突结束。”

;

;佩斯科夫表示，这次释放是土耳其北约盟国在下周的北约峰会之前施加的巨大压力的结果。乌克兰希望在该军事联盟中收到关于其未来成员身份的积极信号。

;

;弗拉基米尔·泽伦斯基在讲话中没有解释为何允许指挥官现在回国。土耳其通讯局没有回应置评请求。

;

;随后在西部城市利沃夫与这些人一起举行的仪式上，弗拉基米尔·泽连斯基感谢埃尔多安帮助确保他们获释，并承诺将所有剩余人员带回家囚犯。

;

;埃尔多安还表示支持泽连斯基希望其国家成为北约军事联盟成员的愿望。

;

;土耳其声称自己是俄罗斯战争的调解者。乌克兰与两国保持着良好的贸易、防务和外交关系。

;

;泽伦斯基表示，战争爆发前，“世界上许多人仍然不明白我们是什么、你们是什么，对我们有什么期望以及我们的英雄是什么。现在大家都明白了。”

;

;许多乌克兰人对这些人的归来表示欢迎。

;

;“终于！有史以来最好的消息。恭喜我们的兄弟们！”在乌克兰东部作战的马克西姆·佐林少校在 Telegram 消息应用程序上表示。

;

;五名指挥官之一的丹尼斯·普罗科彭科 (Denys Prokopenko) 在谈到乌克兰军队在过去一个月发起的反攻时告诉与会者，他的人们“将在战斗中说出我们的话。最重要的是乌克兰已经掌握了战略主动权并正在推进。”

;

;美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯在纪念500天之际称俄罗斯是“公正持久和平的唯一障碍”，承诺“只要需要”就会支持基辅。

;

;法国外交部表示，这个时间框架“必须让俄罗斯认识到它已陷入僵局，并立即停止其非法侵略战争”。

;

;美国最新的支持承诺包括供应广泛禁止的集束弹药的计划。国防部长奥莱克西·雷兹尼科夫承诺这些弹药不会在俄罗斯使用。

;

;乌克兰武装部队总参谋部表示，乌克兰军队周六在东南部两个地区“继续进攻行动”。

;< p>;官员称，乌克兰军队还夺回了支离破碎的东部城市巴赫穆特周围的地区——经过几个月的战斗，俄罗斯军队于五月份占领了该城市。

;分析师称，越南越来越被视为该地区的“地缘政治摇摆国家”说，随着大国努力与东南亚国家建立更密切的军事合作。

;

;上个月末，一艘美国航空母舰和两艘导弹巡洋舰罕见地访问了越南——这只是第三次此类访问这是越南战争结束后双边关系恢复以来的一次访问。

;

;尼米兹级核动力航空母舰罗纳德·里根号停靠在岘港市进行为期六天的访问，航母战斗群指挥官帕特里克·汉尼芬少将称，这是加强美越伙伴关系和“应对海上领域共同挑战的承诺”。

;

;一周前，日本最大的驱逐舰出云号还访问了越南中部海岸的金兰湾港口。日本海军少将西山隆宏表示，东京希望深化与越南海军的定期交流，建立合作关系。

;

;大约在同一时间，印度国防部长拉杰纳特·辛格与来访的越南海军会面后新德里的潘文江将军向河内赠送了一艘印度海军现役导弹护卫舰作为礼物。

;

;国产护卫舰“基尔潘”号是印度向任何国家赠送的第一艘现役军舰。旨在加强越南海军能力。

;

;上个月末，韩国领导人尹锡烈以总统身份首次访问越南，此前双方于 12 月将关系提升为“全面战略伙伴关系” – 首尔和河内均同意以朝鲜核威胁为由加强安全合作。

;

;两国还同意加强国防工业关系以及河内长期以来卷入南中国海的安全合作与北京存在领土争端。

;

;越南禁止芭比娃娃电影展示北京对南中国海的主张

;

;胡志明市大学国际关系讲师 Tam-Sang Huynh社会科学与人文学科教授表示，越南因其位于东南亚中心的位置以及“地缘政治摇摆国家”的地位而受到地区大国的青睐。

;

;“韩国将越南视为理想的地点实现商业联系多元化并扩大国防市场，而印度则需要越南作为加强与东盟关系的桥梁，”Huynh 说，他指的是由 10 个成员国组成的东南亚国家联盟。

;

;“东南亚亚洲将继续承受成为大国竞争雷区的沉重负担。”他补充道。

;

;近年来，韩国已成为亚洲主要的武器出口国——从 2017 年到 2021 年，它向东南亚国家（主要是菲律宾和印度尼西亚）运送了价值略低于 20 亿美元的武器。

;

;据称，这个东亚国家现在也在讨论可能向越南出售武器，因为后者寻求实现武库现代化。

;

;但是，尽管越南在军事上受到大国的“讨好”，黄表示将继续其对冲策略，并不急于升级与美国的伙伴关系。

;

;“如果它没有坏，为什么要修理它？”他说，并补充说，河内领导层需要中国的政治支持，以加强越南共产党的“地位和合法性”。

;

;美国和越南十年前建立了“全面伙伴关系”，现在有传言称正在研究将其升级为“战略”的可能性。

;

;但河内迄今仍保持谨慎态度，主要是因为担心这样做可能会激怒北京或导致中国报复。

;

; p>;

;美国波士顿学院政治学博士生康武（Khang Vu）表示，虽然最近几周主要大国对越南的拉拢是河内“外交平衡”的积极成果。 ”，“越南的首要任务是与中国保持稳定的关系，以降低军事冲突的风险”。

;

;“越南在很大程度上坚持多元化和多边化的中立外交政策，以确保其“不要让中国感到不安，同时扩大与其他大国的外交接触范围。”他说。

;

;Vu 补充说，作为军事上较弱的伙伴，越南必须“每当中国在海上欺凌越南时就获得更多支持”，并且寻求替代安全选择，以防与北京的关系急剧恶化。

;

;5月份，中国调查船向阳红10号在海岸警卫队船只的陪同下进入越南专属经济区，河内指责中国侵犯其主权。< /p>;

;根据中国外交部的一份声明，中国科考船及其护航舰运行了近一个月，“在中国管辖海域进行正常科考活动”，然后返回海南省。< /p>;

;2020年，一艘载有8名船员的越南渔船在有争议的西沙群岛附近被一艘中国船只撞沉。北京表示，越南船只拒绝离开该地区，“突然急转”并撞上了中国船只。

;

;东南亚地区专家、新南威尔士大学名誉教授卡尔·塞耶 (Carl Thayer) 表示在美中紧张局势中，越南利用高层外交作为筹码。

;

;越南总理范明正上个月会见了中国国家主席习近平，同时继续与美国就在中美关系之前建立可能的战略伙伴关系进行谈判今年年底。

;

;越南将与美国有多接近以遏制中国？

;

;“河内的每个战略伙伴都必须评估不与越南合作的成本”，塞耶说，并补充说，越南主动与大国进行外交接触不仅是为了缓解地区紧张局势，也是为了加强其在地区安全中的作用。

;

;Prashanth Parameswaran，东盟专家周刊的创始人、美国威尔逊中心智囊团的研究员表示，主要大国将越南视为一个军事能力强、外交活跃、经济重要且政治稳定的国家。

;

;“越南的战略培养多元化关系有助于管理风险并最大限度地利用机会，但这种多向外交政策方法也需要仔细校准，而当地缘政治环境恶化时，这一点就更具挑战性。”他说。

;勇敢者冒着生命危险，被誉为“中国的好邻居”拯救一名在 14 楼阳台上摇摇欲坠的四岁男孩。

;

;拼车司机王俊毅正在家里为刚考完大学的妻子和女儿准备晚餐

;

;一时间，中国东部江苏省本应安静的家庭之夜，被王妻子的尖叫声打断了。

;

;当她走向阳台时去收集晒干的衣服时，她听到了求救声。绝望的哀求来自楼上的公寓。

;

;不知何故，住在那里的四岁男孩设法爬上了自家公寓阳台的玻璃墙。

;

;唯一能阻止他坠落必死的就是他的小手抓住了玻璃框的顶部，而他的脚尖也抓住了阳台下五厘米宽的部分。

;

;转眼间，王冲出去，爬上自家玻璃阳台墙的顶部，站在狭窄的框架上，伸出右手扶住了重约20公斤的男孩的脚后跟。

;

;此时事发时，王先生唯一能从13楼公寓坠落的，是他的左手紧紧地抓着玻璃框。随后，他的妻子和女儿在隔壁老太太的搀扶下，赶来扶住他的双腿，防止他摔倒。

;

;这一生死攸关的场面被一名居民拍了下来。

;

;据易姓居民称，他们就这样保持了六分钟，物业人员才赶到，全力营救。

;

;江苏电视台报道称，楼上一家人将儿子独自留在家中睡着了，等他醒来时，男孩已经爬上了阳台的玻璃框。

;

;王先生因从事司机工作而行动不便，他说他是凭本能行事。< /p>;

;救援人员的行动引起了人们的注意。

;

;王先生及其家人、物业管理人员以及伸出援手的老年邻居都被当地政府授予了勇敢奖。

;

; >;

;王的英雄事迹也为他在大陆社交媒体上赢得了掌声，许多人称赞他是“中国的好邻居”。

;

;“他冒着生命危险拯救了他的邻居！”一位人士说道。

;

;“他所做的事情很棒。毕竟他只是一个没有受过任何训练的普通人。非常勇敢。”还有人说。

;

;有人表示，这让他们想起了中国东部浙江省的一名送货员彭庆林为救一名溺水妇女而从12米高的桥上跳下的故事。< /p>;

;彭因撞击水面而遭受压缩性骨折和肌肉损伤。

; Sun, 09 Jul 2023 09:20:04 +0800 China’s 3D printers are gaining popularity among US consumers, but can they shake their geeky reputation?https://www.scmp.com/tech/article/3226757/chinas-3d-printers-are-gaining-popularity-among-us-consumers-can-they-shake-their-geeky-reputation?utm_source=rss_feed

;当 3D 打印机在 2010 年左右首次普及时，高科技机械的成本和和一辆汽车一样重。如今，得益于新一代的中国制造商，3D 打印机就像微波炉一样触手可及。

;

;Elegoo 成立于 2015 年，生产消费级 3D 打印机，价格仅为 9 公斤低至 200 美元至 300 美元。它们是在中国南方科技中心深圳的一家 25,000 平方米工厂生产的。

;

;“我们的目标是降低进入门槛，将令人着迷的 3D 打印技术带入公众的车库、地下室和餐桌。联合创始人兼首席营销官 Kevin Wang 在最近的一次采访中告诉《南华早报》。

;

;Wang 表示，3D 打印机以前仅限于大学 STEM 系和工业设施，但现在该技术取得了长足进步可以使其成为与传统 2D 打印机一样的家居用品。

;

;该公司表示，自 2018 年以来，其销量已超过 100 万台，员工人数已超过 500 名，通过在线方式运送到 70 多个国家和地区市场，包括由 Shopify、亚马逊和拥有《华盛顿邮报》的阿里巴巴集团运营的市场。其最大的市场是美国。

;

;该公司表示，虽然 Elegoo 的紧凑型机器通常只能打印不大于鞋盒的物品，但可以打印单个零件，然后组装成更大的物品，从而提供无限的用例。

;

;“任何你有的想法，任何你想要定制或无法从公开市场购买的物品，3D 打印解决方案都可以使之成为可能。”王说。

;

;而拥有 3D 建模的客户他补充说，具有设计经验的人可能更容易定制自己的作品，但由于在线提供的教程和现成印刷设计市场不断增长，先验知识并不是先决条件。

;

;尽管 Elegoo 雄心勃勃，但其产品尚未突破小众市场和以爱好者为中心的市场。

;

;“目前，主要客户包括游戏玩家、角色扮演者和电影爱好者，”王指着绿巨人的 3D 雕像说道 –漫威影业电影中的巨型绿色超级英雄 - 在他的办公桌上。

;

;预计到 2031 年，全球可动人偶和桌面游戏市场将分别达到 153 亿美元和 41 亿美元，而全球角色扮演服装市场根据 Allied Market Research 的数据，到 2030 年，预计 3D 打印市场规模将从 2020 年的 46 亿美元增至 230 亿美元。

;

;尽管如此，Elegoo 希望随着产品变得更加多样化，3D 打印将迎来更多元化的客户群。更易于访问和宣传。

;

;该公司最新的营销活动将打印机推销给日常用户，他们可以使用它来创建定制的小工具和家居装饰品。与此同时，3D打印技术为中小企业、企业家和创作者提供了新的商业价值主张。

;

;“例如，好莱坞的电影制片人正在使用3D打印技术为他们的电影制作道具。”电影，而航空航天和汽车工程师则使用它们为合作伙伴 3D 打印原型零部件。

;

;亚马逊评论显示 Elegoo 的机器也被客户用来制作或测试珠宝和原型水肺潜水部件等设备，并更换各种日常用品中丢失或损坏的部件。

;

;虽然这些机器配备了用于设计 3D 图像的免费开源软件，但客户需要购买打印材料：固体塑料丝或液体树脂，具体取决于型号。

;

;一件大型且复杂的物品可能使用大约 1 公斤的树脂，在亚马逊上的价格从 10 美元到 50 美元不等。更有经验的用户可能还想投资单独的付费设计软件。

;

;香港司法机构将评估在法庭上更广泛地使用人工智能 (AI)，但暂时没有计划让法官使用ChatGPT工具来加快工作速度。

;

;法官和司法人员使用人工智能实时粤语语音转文字的试点计划将会完成司法机构发言人表示，今年第三季度，我们将检讨和评估让所有法官和司法人员更广泛地使用语音转文字技术作为协助他们到今年年底在法庭和分庭履行司法职能。”他说。

;

;该审判于 2021 年开始，使用了两家当地科技公司的软件产品，但初步结果显示，司法部门表示，“还有很大的改进空间”，尤其是在抄写法律术语方面。

;

;审判中的十名法官和官员正在使用该软件的改进版本来制作笔记，供自己在法律诉讼过程中参考。

;

;发言人表示，法院将禁止使用 ChatGPT，因为该工具在该市无法直接使用。

;

;去年年底出现的人工智能工具能够利用网上提供的信息，以文笔优美且语法正确的类人语言快速回答问题或撰写论文。

;

;“考虑到香港尚未获授权使用ChatGPT发言人表示，鉴于其潜在的数据安全风险，司法机构没有计划允许法官和司法人员利用ChatGPT进行司法工作。

;

;香港推出首个面向初中生的人工智能课程中学生

;

;其名称中的 GPT 代表“生成式预训练变压器”，这意味着尽管该技术工具具有类似人类的反应，但其编程主要是从互联网和其他来源获取信息，目前仅限于 2021 年之前可用的材料。

;

;《华盛顿邮报》测试了 ChatGPT，提供了两个案件的相关法律意见书并要求其作出裁决，但该聊天机器人拒绝对其中任何一个案件作出判决，称它没有可以访问实时案件或法庭诉讼程序，并且做出法律决定需要有执照的专业人士。

;

;该市的律师和律师事务所一直在使用人工智能工具进行文件审查和尽职调查工作，其中一些冒险into generative AI, which could produce new content from a data bank.

;

;Lawyers told the Post there was room for the sector to use AI, but the technology could not replace humans in the judiciary as algorithms could not replicate critical thinking and had no legal knowledge or empathy.

;

;“What these generative AI tools have done is that they have sped up what might have taken lawyers hours to do, provided lawyers know how to use the chatbot themselves, ” said Joshua Chu Kiu-wah, a solicitor specialising in technology law.

;

;Assistant Professor Eliza Mik, who researches legal technologies at Chinese University, said AI tools could not verify facts or digest legal knowledge, and needed users to steer responses by providing legal knowledge.

;

;“They do not understand the world, they do not understand or know the law,” she cautioned.

;

;Mik and Chu warned against possible “ hallucinations”, referring to when generative AI tools produced logical but factually incorrect statements.

;

;In May, a judge in New York fined two lawyers US$5,000 for submitting a legal brief referencing made-up cases and citations. Lawyer Steven Schwartz, who wrote the brief, admitted that he used ChatGPT but was unaware it might include fabricated cases.

;

;In France, using AI to analyse and predict judges' behaviour was banned in 2019, after a lawyer and machine learning expert published his analysis of French judges' patterns in asylum case rulings.

;

;US lawyer sorry after ChatGPT creates fake cases for court filing

;

;But on mainland China, judges are mandated to consult an AI system for every case and provide written explanations if they digress from the machine's suggestion.

;

;The AI system, which remains controversial on the mainland, automatically screens court cases for references, recommends laws and regulations, drafts legal documents and alters perceived human errors, if any, in a verdict.

;

;While authorities praised the system's efficiency, critics were concerned about judges not challenging it and the possible erosion of judicial power.

;

;Hong Kong Law Society president Chan Chak-ming said lawyers in the city must understand the nature and limits of AI tools to fulfil their duty of competence to clients, if they wished to rely on the technology.

;

;Tech lawyer Chu said generative AI could be used to produce basic templates for lawyers and judges to work on as a way to improve the quality and speed of legal submissions, and could help clear the courts' backlog of work.

;

;“As long as the rationale for a decision is there, an AI-assisted writing of the draft would not be that bad either,” he said.

;

;However, he added that the judiciary would have to develop its own AI system for data safety with a policy to train its staff to use it.

;

;Associate Professor Stuart Hargreaves, of Chinese University's law faculty, said that as the technology improved, AI could be used to help lawyers and judges gather and process information.

;

;But legal decisions had to be made by humans because of the severity of the consequences, he stressed, adding that current AI tools performed poorly on tasks that required value judgment and niche knowledge.

;

;“While there will be space in the future for AI to assist in legal knowledge gathering and processing, ultimately a human must take responsibility for the output,” he said.

;Brazil's President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva on Saturday met his Colombian counterpart Gustavo Petro to build momentum for a coming regional summit on the Amazon rainforest and enhance efforts for its protection.

;

;The encounter took place in Colombia's Leticia, a town in the Amazon's triple border region between Colombia, Brazil and Peru, where organised crime has recently increased its hold.

;

;The meeting aimed to lay groundwork for the Amazon Summit the Brazilian government is organising in Belem next month. That summit will be attended by leaders of the countries party to the Amazon Cooperation Treaty Organisation, made up of Bolivia, Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, Guyana, Peru, Suriname, and Venezuela.

;

;Lula is pushing for a joint declaration from the summit, which would be presented at the United Nation's climate conference, known as COP28, in Dubai in November.

;

;“We will have to demand together that rich countries fulfil their commitments,” Lula said in Leticia, sitting next to Petro.

;

;The final document will comprise measures for the sustainable development of the Amazon, protecting the biome, and promoting social inclusion, science, technology and innovation while valuing Indigenous peoples and their knowledge, Brazil's presidential palace said in a statement.

;

;“Joint action of the countries that share the Amazon biome is fundamental for facing the multiple challenges in the region,” the statement said.

;

;Brazil Amazon deforestation drops 34 per cent in Lula's first 6 months

;

;One challenge faced is the tightened grip of organised crime, particularly in tri-border regions like where Leticia is located. British journalist Dom Phillips and Indigenous activist Bruno Pereira were killed in the neighbouring Javari valley region last year.

;

;These areas have become “violent hotspots,” according to a report by the UN Office on Drugs and Crime released in June. It noted criminal groups are simultaneously engaged in cocaine production trafficking, as well as natural resource exploitation.

;

;Indigenous groups are “disproportionately affected” by the criminal nexus in the Amazon, the report added, pointing to forced displacements, mercury poisoning and other health-related impacts as well as increased exposure to violence.

;

;In 2019, Colombia, Bolivia, Ecuador, Brazil, Peru, Guyana and Suriname signed the Leticia Pact to strengthen coordinated actions for the preservation of the natural resources of the Amazon.

;

;But the goals are vague and lack ways to measure progress, said Marcio Astrini, executive secretary of the Climate Observatory, an umbrella organisation of environmental groups.

;

;“It's a letter of ambitions. We hope that in Leticia they (Lula and Petro) will increase and clarify their ambitions,” said Astrini.

;

;Since taking office in January, Lula has strived to put environmental protection and respect for Indigenous peoples' rights at the heart of his third term. He successful pursued resumption of international donations for the Amazon Fund that combats deforestation, launched a military campaign to eject illegal miners from Yanomami territory, committed to ending all illegal deforestation by 2030 and restarted the demarcation of Indigenous areas.

;

;Lula's approach contrasts sharply with the actions of his predecessor, Jair Bolsonaro. Under the far-right leader's term, deforestation soared to a 15-year high, and environmental restrictions were weakened. Deforestation fell by 33.6 per cent

;

;during the first six months of Lula's term, according to satellite data the Brazilian government released this week from the National Institute for Space Research, a federal agency.

;

;Petro has also been vocal about the need to halt destruction in the Amazon. The Colombian leader has proposed the creation of multilateral 20-year financing fund to support farming communities contributing to deforestation. The idea is to compensate them for conservation and regenerative activities instead.

;

;Historically, collaboration between Brazil and Colombia, which share a border longer than 1,500km (about 900 miles), has been lacking, according to Wagner Ribeiro, a geographer and expert in environmental policy from the University of Sao Paulo.

;

;“We hope that opportunities for academic cooperation will arise from the meeting, which will later generate public policies that promote environmental conservation,” Ribeiro said.

;;2023.07.09 06:00;
;;

;This is the second story in a about China's employment environment, from migrant workers and fresh graduates to new job sources and the private sector.

;

;For less than a cup of coffee at most major chains, a migrant worker in a major Chinese city can rent a bed for the night. But oftentimes, that is contingent on finding work and getting paid that day.

;

;In the southeastern outskirts of Beijing, amid a record-breaking heatwave scorching the capital, migrant workers starved of both food and jobs still venture out to make a living in the sweltering sun.

;

;Wang Ke, 36, is among those who haven't had a full stomach in a while. He and his band of fellow job-hunters never pass up a chance to ask people, “Do you need workers?”

;

;But the group too often returns in disappointment, wondering again when they might get their next meal, and if they will even have a roof over their head that night. Beds generally cost between 25 yuan (US$3.45) and 30 yuan a night.

;

;“A job comes by only every few days, and a group of people rush to seize it,” Wang, originally from the central province of Henan, said from Majuqiao, once the capital city's largest labour service market, where employment agencies and recruiters shout out menial job offerings on the street, paying usually about 100 yuan (US$13.80) or so a day.

;

;“I am willing to work any kind of odd job, but I haven't had any luck in four days. Ninety per cent of the people here are like me. No one can make money here; being able to fill my stomach would be the most beautiful thing ever.”

;

;People like Wang can only wander the streets at night, finding vacant places to sleep wherever they can, changing locations several times a night to areas without people – safer areas with less chance of unwanted interactions.

;

;The current need for migrant workers may serve as a barometer for the recovery of China's economic activities, which has gradually lost steam amid a property slump, dwindling export demand holding back China's manufacturing sector, and dampened confidence among consumers and investors.

;

;China's factory activities contracted for a third straight month in June, further putting pressure on the world's largest exporter of goods.

;

;“The most direct reason is there aren't jobs that suit them, as Beijing is relieved of functions non-essential to its role as China's capital, many labour-intensive industries have moved out of Beijing, and the labour opportunities have left with them,” said Yuan Xin, a demography professor at Nankai University in Tianjin.

;

;Timeline of decline. How has China's demographic crisis emerged?

;

;Beijing has been pushing for the removal of “non-essential institutions” from China's capital to the Xiongan New Area in neighbouring Hebei province. And many lower-end manufacturing businesses have taken the brunt, slashing the need for migrant workers without technical skills.

;

;“We are even worse off than beggars,” Wang added. “Beggars can ask for help, while we are too ashamed, and many resort to rummaging through garbage bins to survive.”

;

;China had around 296 million migrant workers at the end of 2022, and in the first quarter of this year, their average monthly income dropped to 4,504 yuan, from a monthly average of 4,615 yuan last year, according to official statistics.

;

;In quantifiable terms, that lost income could represent three more nights that a migrant worker spends on the streets every month, in situations comparable to Wang's.

;

;But the data can hardly depict the bleakness of work prospects for the older generations of migrants, who are often too old to be office-building security guards, electronics factory workers, or perhaps amusement park staff. And they're often rejected outright for jobs that necessitate fast learning, or when a company wants staff to appear younger.

;

;And for many migrant workers, almost exclusively rural residents, there is no end in sight to their work, as they will not be able to retire, due to a lack of savings and limited pension coverage.

;

;Despite bleak economic growth and sluggish factory activities last year due to China's draconian zero-Covid measures, the conditions gave rise to a surge in demand for temporary workers, including security guards, workers for Covid testing booths, and delivery workers – all of which paid relatively well, sometimes more than 10,000 yuan a month, enabling migrant workers to cash in.

;

;“As soon as the pandemic [control measures] ended, it became difficult to find jobs,” said another migrant worker, in his forties, who declined to be identified. It had been two weeks since he found work.

;

;“Loading work pays 150 yuan for 12 hours, and you have to bring your own meals. Even some big enterprises pay less than Beijing's minimum wage,” which is just over 25 yuan an hour.

;

;Before the pandemic, Wang worked in Zhejiang province and owned his own business, was a sales manager at China Mobile, and led a large team of security guards.

;

;After nationwide restrictions were lifted, Wang decided to test his luck in Beijing. And he's not ready to throw in the towel yet.

;

;“No one wants to go home without having made money. Who wouldn't want to return home with glory and triumph? 'Until one arrives in Beijing, one does not realise the insignificance of their position,' I want to check it out,” he said.

;

;Looking for a job in China

;

;Meanwhile, younger temporary workers – mostly students working summer holidays – have more opportunities. But this year, as the number of youth seeking odd jobs has increased, the monthly wage has shrunk in Beijing.

;

;“This year there are more students looking for jobs, as last year they were all locked down at home,” said a recruiting agent for youthful temporary workers, surnamed Li, whose company is near Majuqiao.

;

;Because students can work for such short periods – often just a handful of weeks – they have less leverage to negotiate and are often paid less.

;

;Li said the monthly compensation for stage construction workers is about 3,500 yuan this year, including bed and board, for 12 hours a day, 30 days a month, with no breaks. That's down from the 3,800 yuan monthly average last year.

;

;That sort of difference could equate to not sleeping in a bed nine times a month.

;

;Further illustrating the rising struggle among jobseekers, particularly young adults, is the youth unemployment rate, which has lately been setting record highs on a monthly basis.

;

;The jobless rate in the 16-24 age group has been on an upward trajectory since 2020 and is expected to rise further in July and August, as a record 11.58 million university graduates are set to leave campus and flood the job market this year, posing a challenge to Beijing's post-coronavirus recovery efforts.

;

;In May, the jobless rate among that younger demographic hit a record of 20.8 per cent, up from the previous high of 20.4 per cent in April.

;

;The overall urban surveyed jobless rate in May, however, remained unchanged from April at 5.2 per cent. June's figures should be released in a couple of weeks.

;

;In the manufacturing hubs of southern China, demand for such young workers also remains ample, but incomes have declined compared with last year, due to a reduction in the overtime working hours at small and medium-sized enterprises.

;

;“Factories offer about 15 to 17 yuan per hour for [temporary workers this year], down from last year's 18 to 20 yuan,” according to a recruitment agent in Guangdong surnamed Li, who declined to give her full name.

;

;While exporting manufacturers cut full-time workers and hire more temporary workers instead, to save operating costs, the cost of living expenses have barely changed, including food and accommodation.

;

;China cuts marriage red tape for migrant workers as population crisis looms

;

;“The main labour force in my factory is now mainly temporary workers. I pay them about 260 yuan a day for over 12 hours of work,” said Wang Jie, a manufacturer of parts for boots and shoes, in Guangdong's Dongguan city.

;

;He said that to save costs, he had cut most of his full-time workers to less than 20, down about two-thirds from last year,

;

;“Before the epidemic, we used to be paid 7,000 yuan [a month] or more in peak seasons [for at least 60 hours per week], but now we make about 5,000 yuan, including a free meal,” said a worker at a listed electrical company in Guangzhou.

;

;She also talked about how factories in migrant workers' hinterland hometowns are seeing longer off-season stretches, making them hard to rely on for a living, which drives workers elsewhere, with wide-reaching economic implications.

;

;“We all cherish the stable employment, especially when we hear that more and more SMEs nearby are cutting jobs,” she said.

;

;1.4 billion people and shrinking — China's population problem visually explained

;

;Elsewhere, in eastern China's Zhejiang province, sources say factories are finding it much easier to recruit temporary workers this year – even in the last couple of months as the year has gone on, and workers are generally more reluctant to leave a job midyear.

;

;Lu Zhou, an operations director at an original equipment manufacturer (OEM) factory in eastern China's Jiangsu province, expressed a similar assessment in his province.

;

;In May or June of previous years, most labourers worked for fixed factories in Jiangsu, and it was very difficult to recruit workers at this time, but this year it's been easy, he said.

;

;“The labour cost … is about 8,000 yuan per worker. Workers can get about 5,000 yuan a month, working at least 60 hours a week, after the social security contribution,” Lu said. “One obvious change is that this year's social security contributions [such as social insurance and taxes] have risen again.

;

;“Many workers are reluctant to pay [into social security], and that feeling is stronger now than in previous years. Many workers probably expect that social welfare will become inadequate in a future ageing society.”
